question-text: Rewrite the sentences according to the instructions given in brackets.

set1.question-item-text: Bagan is the most famous ancient city in Myanmar. We will visit there next summer. (Join the sentences, using ‘nouns in apposition’.)
We do not believe him and neither does she. (Join the sentences, using ‘either...or’/ ‘neither...nor’.)
Zaw Zaw asked Mya Mya why she had not come to their Soan-kyway the day before. (Change the sentence into direct specch.)
Workers weave silk thread into beautiful shirts. (Change the sentence into the passive voice.)
I had two hours to spare for shopping. I couldn’t find the suit I wanted. (Join the sentences using an appropriate subordinating conjunction ‘in order that’/ ‘provided that’/ ‘even though’.)
A police officer stopped and arrested the robbers. His car was parked at the next corner. (Join the sentences, using an appropriate pronoun/ relative adverb.)
<u className='underline'>The acrobat</u> crossed the tightrope steadily. (Use ‘It is/was... who/that...’.)
He is found innocent, or he is found guilty. Nonetheless, his reputation is permanently damaged. (Join the sentence, beginning with ‘No matter...’.)
She didn’t switch on the lights, so she fell over the chair. (Use the third conditional.)
The teachers are giving the students a day off. The principal is giving the students a day off. (Join the sentences, beginning with ‘Not only... but also’.)

set2.question-item-text: Alexander Pope is a prominent poet of the Augustan age. He is best known for his satirical verse. (Join the sentences, using ‘nouns in apposition’.)
They had checked the weather forecast. They set out on their journey. (Join the sentences, using ‘after’.)
Computer games are more popular with today’s teenagers than horror films. (Use ‘not as ...as’.)
If you (follow) your teacher’s guidelines, you (pass) the exam. (Use ‘the third conditional’.)
No sooner did I finish writing my essay than I heard the bell ring. (Change the sentence, beginning with ‘As soon as ...’.)
As he did not know the way to Ocean Supermarket, he asked a passer-by for help. (Use ‘a participle phrase’.)
They did not have enough food to eat. They did not have money to go to a restaurant. (Join the sentences, using ‘neither ... nor’.)
She cleans her room every day. Nobody urges her. (Join the sentences, beginning with ‘Without + V-ing’.)
“What shall I do if you don’t accompany me to the concert tonight?” Thazin said to her friend. (Change the sentence into ‘the reported speech’.)
The girl spoke to the teddy bear softly. She thought it were her best friend. (Use ‘as if’.)

set3.question-item-text: The spicy chicken curry that the head chef cooked for the special guests was very delicious. (Omit the relative pronoun.)
<u className='underline'>Cambodia</u> has become the world’s second-largest producer of raw cashew nuts. (Use ‘It is/was... who/that...’.)
Many students came to the farewell dinner. We couldn’t get a seat.(Join the sentences, using ‘so...that’/ ‘such...that’.)
The manager drank his coffee slowly. He thought about the problem. (Join the sentences, using a participle phrase.)
Rope skipping is an enjoyable activity for children. Hoop rolling is an enjoyable activity for children, too. (Join the sentences, using ‘both...and’.)
The wildfire started because someone at the campsite was careless.(Use the zero / first / second / third conditional.)
Hnin Hnin said to me, “What were you doing when I phoned you this morning?” (Change the sentence into the reported speech.)
My mother always goes to bed only after she (say) her prayers. (Use the correct tense of the verb in brackets.)
Did the child pick up the toys on the floor and put them into a drawer? (Change the sentence into the passive voice.)
The old swimmer broke the tournament record again on the very first day of the competition. (Use an introductory phrase.)

set4.question-item-text: She didn’t check the map, so she got lost. (Use the third conditional.)
The students are organising a cultural festival at the moment. (Change the sentence into the passive voice.)
Mya Hninsi wrote a best-selling novel. She was a famous writer. (Join the sentences, using nouns in apposition.)
She (write) a report all morning. (Use the correct tense of the verb given in brackets.)
She said to Hla Hla,"I am meeting you at the café tomorrow." (Change the sentence into the reported speech.)
She is very young. She cannot drive a car. (Join the sentences, using 'too...to'/enough. ..to'.)
He is a talented musician. He is a skilled painter. (Join the sentences, using 'not only...but also')
As he was overwhelmed by the unexpected events, he couldn't decide how to proceed. (Use a participle phrase.)
She was very excited. It seemed like she had won a prize. (Join the sentences, using 'as if'.)
<u className='underline'>The manager</u> approved the project proposal and allocated the necessary resources. (Use 'It is/was ... who/that...'.)

set5.question-item-text: The movie is being shown at Globe Theatre. It is also being shown at neighbourhood theatres, (Join the sentences, using ‘both ...and’)
Ma Ma will attend the meeting. She will send a representative. (Join the sentences, using ‘either ..or’ / ‘neither ...nor’.)
Thuzar painted the entire house green last month. (Change the sentence into the passive voice.)
<u className='underline'>The beautiful scenery</u> attracts tourists to the area. (Use ‘It is/ It was ... who/ that ...’.)
Muyar excelled in her studies. She also participated in numerous extracurricular activities. (Join t h e sentences, beginning with ‘Not only ... but also’.)
It does not matter how often I warn them. They keep gambling. (Join the sentences, beginning with ‘No matter ...’)
I turn the page of the magazine. I saw her beautiful photograph. (Join the sentences, using a participle phrase.)
The chef impressed all the guests, preparing the meal with great care.(Use an introductory phrase)
The prices on the menu in that restaurant were very high. Therefore, we didn’t go there. (Use the third conditional.)
Sandar asked him whether he could help her with her homework. (Change the sentence into direct speech.)

set6.question-item-text: Although she is not a professional singer, she performs like a music icon. (Join the sentences, using ‘as if/ as though’.)
The war caused destruction and death. It caused generations of hatred between the two communities too. (Join the sentences, using ‘not only ...but also’.)
The problem seems to be difficult, but I’ll find a solution. (Join the sentences, using ‘No matter how.....)
We did not save more money, and thus, we could not buy a bigger house.(Use ‘the third conditional’.)
The explorers discovered an ancient city hidden in the jungle. (Change the sentence into the passive voice.)
After he had read the book, he wrote a detailed review. (Use a participle phrase.)
The storm caused <u className='underline'>severe damage</u> to the town. (Use ‘It is/ It was ... who/ that...’)
She failed to submit the assignment on time. She received a lower grade.(Join the sentences using ‘as a result’.)
He said to me, “When I reach the airport, I’ll call you.” (Change the sentence into the reported speech.)
He worked very hard. He completed the project on time. (Join the sentences, using ‘enough to’.)

set7.question-item-text: Our neighbours are boring people. We rarely visit them. (Join the sentences, using ‘so...that’/ ‘such...that’.)
Here are your shoes and they (just clean). (Use the correct tense of the verb in brackets.)
Active listening plays an essential role in effective collaboration. Problem-solving also plays an essential role in effective collaboration. (Join the sentences, using ‘both...and’.)
<u className='underline'>A low-salt diet with minimal processed foods</u> can reduce the risk of premature death by protecting our kidneys. (Use ‘It is / was ... who / that ...’)
The housekeeper put on a serious face. She began to tell the story.(Join the sentences, using a participle phrase.)
Tokyo offers its visitors an unlimited choice of shopping and entertainment. Tokyo is the capital of Japan. (Join the sentences, using nouns in apposition.)
Ko Ko said to me, “Did you throw away the old magazines on this table yesterday?” (Change the sentence into the reported speech.)
Thu Thu didn’t go to the get-together party because she had to work late. (Use the zero / first / second /third conditional.)
The slim leather briefcase she held in her gloved hand was particularly impressive. (Use an introductory phrase.)
Did a passer-by rescue the stray puppy which got its head stuck in a tin can? (Change the sentence into the passive voice.)

set8.question-item-text: I did not fall while I was cycling. I did not break my leg while I was cycling, (Join the sentences, using ‘neither ... nor’.)
The story was very interesting. I read it in one sitting. (Join the sentences, using ‘such ... that’)
Patricia asked me, “Did you visit the zoo last month?” (Change the sentence into the reported speech.)
The government has provided all the villages in this area with fresh water. (Change into passive form.)
If you spend more, you cannot save much money. (Join the sentences, using ‘The morelless/. er..., the more/less/-er ‘.)
They climbed the mountain. No one guided them. (Join the sentences, using ‘without+V. ing’.)
The team won the championship. It also set a new record. (Join the sentences, beginning with ‘Not only ... ’.)
Sandi was awarded first prize in the essay competition. She was praised by her friends. (Join the sentences, using ‘as a result of’.)
I did not have enough money. I did not buy a car? (Use ‘third conditional’.)
Her workload is extremely demanding. She makes herself accessible to people, anyway. (Join the sentences, beginning with ‘No matter’.)

set9.question-item-text: No sooner had they had their dinner than the ceiling crashed onto the dining table. (Use ‘As soon as ...’.)
I was not involved in the project. He was not also involved in it.(Join the sentences, using ‘Neither ... nor’)
Swiftlets are tiny birds. However, they can spend ten months in flight without taking a break. (Join the sentences, beginning with ‘Although’.)
The gardener whispered a few words of encouragement to his plants. He thought they were alive. (Join the sentences, using ‘as if’.)
At present, people use a GPS device instead of a guidebook when they do not know the way to their destination. (Use ‘a participle phrase’.)
They checked the weather forecast. Then, they went for a picnic yesterday. (Join the sentences, using ‘before’.)
You will not be allowed to go into the library if you do not have your personal library card. (Use ‘without + V-ing’.)
They renovated the old building and converted it into a cinema.(Change the sentence into ‘the passive voice’.)
Our monitor should be a bit considerate towards his classmates to be a good leader. (Use ‘an introductory phrase’.)
Ma Ma said to her sister, “Will you come and sit on this sofa if you are free?” (Change the sentence into ‘the reported speech’.)

set10.question-item-text: Experts say that the Amazon rainforest comprises around 50% of all the rainforests in the world.
Thet Htar did not have time to study for the test. She did not do very well.
The boy said to his brother, “You don’t have to stay in here with me, if it bothers you”.
The growth of the internet was responsible for really speeding up communication.
If he (make) a stupid mistake, he (win) the competition.
A dog was barking at a delivery man. It thought he was a burglar.
If you spend time in nature, you will be free from stress.
Yin Kay held up her phone and started recording.
The relationship between diet and nutrition is important. The influence of environmental factors on them is important.
She always listens patiently to her friends, even when their stories are repetitive.
